utterances.sentences: No, you know what? This is good. We shouldn't know. We're the rebels.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They don't want to play that game.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is that American press to go -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let them disappearing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But my problem -- but my problem I don't think that you said, hey, why is he bothering to even meet with the mayor? Why should he meet with the mayor? The guy is a mayor. He is a world leader. But he's got to meet with Theresa May who is having trouble with Brexit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, he is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And what does he say about Brexit? Theresa May, you should have done better. You should have done this. You should have more like me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, that's our representative.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But she is the -- my point is, why would you meet with the mayor? Meeting with Theresa May. She is like the leader of leader of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but he is the one who has been undermining her and I don't think that's polite. By the way, Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If you put on that hat, I think you would look --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you'd look -- you'd look the same exact outfit. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There is the hat. Go, Emily, go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Where is the hat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Come everybody.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I await my invitation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Hey, one last question. How does Peter feel about the John Cleese stuff? Does he? But John Cleese get -- we can talk about it during the break.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You know Peter. Like you can imagine how he feels. He's like you'll always get in trouble for speaking the truth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right. I'll leave it at that. Leave it at that. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I didn't even know what that means. OK. Two 2020 Democrats getting booed by their party for bashing socialism and Medicare for all. The video next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Democratic Party divisions in the spotlight as 2020 hopefuls spoke at this weekend's California Democratic Party convention. Two contenders being booed when they went against the party's growing progressive agenda. First up, former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper takes a stance against socialism. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: FMR. GOV. JOHN HICKENLOOPER (D-CO)
utterances.sentences: If we want to beat Donald Trump and achieve big progressive goals, socialism is not the answer.

utterances.speaker: HICKENLOOPER
utterances.sentences: I was re-elected -- I was re-elected in a purple state in 2014, one of the worst years for Democrats in a quarter century. You know, if we're not careful, we're going to end up helping to re-elect the worst president in American history.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And former Maryland Congressman John Delaney also got an earful from the crowd when he criticized Medicare for all.

utterances.speaker: FMR. REP. JOHN DELANEY (D-MD)
utterances.sentences: What we need as Democrats to build an economy that works but it's got to be with smart policies. Medicare for all may sound good. But it's actually, not good policy nor is it good politics. I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: DELANEY
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you. A hundred.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. So, this was, Greg, a California state convention.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And so, it's basically who goes to the California state convention on a summer weekend, the very faithful, the most activists and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We saw them with the personification of Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They went on to -- he went on to Twitter and said, hey, if you guys want to win, don't be crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He got ratioed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he got ratioed. He got ratioed. He was like, they were basically booing the adult in the room. And the adult understands that to get, you know, to have goals you need means. You need to create in order then to make or spread around. And socialism just takes over the means of production and that doesn't work. So, I mean, it is -- I mean, I thought Hickenlooper was brave. That's not good for them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because he was like, I was thinking of your book, "The Bible of Unspeakable Truths." He told a truth. And at least now, though, we are talking about Hickenlooper.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Really? Are we, though? I think we are talking about socialism. I am going to say this again, because it's worth repeating.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Democratic candidate can't win the primary without socialism but they can't win the general with it. And that's the catch 22 that they face. I'm beginning to think socialism is just a wrecking ball to destroy capitalism. Because no one really believes and understands how socialism is going to work because it has never anywhere. It has never worked in Venezuela. They tried Medicare for all in Vermont. Obamacare failed nationally. Socialism doesn't actually work. It's just used to destroy capitalism. So actually, the people pushing socialism are just anarchists. Over to you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I must say, I'm so interested in this. First of all, I think it's a fever dream on the part of Republicans to think that somehow Democrats are going so far left. Hickenlooper, let's talk about Hickenlooper even though I don't think he is going anywhere. But let's talk about Hickenlooper. You say Hickenlooper gets booed. Hickenlooper is a strong progressive, Jesse. Hickenlooper, for example, he talks about capitalism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But still got booed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He still got booed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. On the socialism because I think he put it out there in a way. And I would pick up on the point made earlier. That this is a California Democratic convention. So, you are getting a representation that is the far left. Then that's like saying you have a convention of the Freedom Caucus and it represents all Republicans. I don't think so. Anyway, to my mind, Hickenlooper is talking about capitalism being broken. He says there are only two companies in America that sell 80 percent of all the hardware goods in the country. He says that's not right. What happened to forcing back against the monopoly so the little guy has a chance to open a corner store, or a neighborhood store and do well. That's not what's happening. We have fewer and fewer companies being started in America. That's not evidence of what it takes to have a solid middle-class growth in America. So, if you are talking about Hickenlooper, remember, he is a strong progressive. It's Republicans who want to label everything socialism. And what he was saying was, don't fall into the Republican trap because then they'll all say we're all socialists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But they still booed him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. But, Juan, the great American success story is because of capitalism, it's not because of socialism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. It's because we've --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You can now say the best economy we've had in 30 years --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, what I'm saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- because capitalism is broken.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Before Emily comes, let me just quickly respond.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because capitalism has been unleashed successfully.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. You can't. You have to understand. We -- I mean, everything from child labor to monopolies, to what happens in 2008 and 2009 with unregulated Wall Street almost crashing our economy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, talk about monopoly --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We had to restrain capitalism.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- the Trump administration actually just took anti-monopolistic action against some of the big Silicon Valley company.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can we get Emily in?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What I was saying, we have when you think about income inequality, we have equality.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Income inequality is big in California --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. It's big --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- the Democrats have a super majority.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Go, Emily.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Emily, Bernie Sanders was in The New York Times today. I won't read the whole thing but he has an op-ed, basically saying that lays out his economic argument. And he also took aim at capitalism and the wealthy saying that we've got it all wrong here in America.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes. And I think that goes into what you are saying where right now that's the best argument. I think it's a -- we are seeing two responses to this, which is either appeasing the Democratic minority of the socialists. Bernie, obviously he's the O.G. He firmly believes it. People like Governor Inslee, however, who came on after Hickenlooper personifies to me kind of personifies that capitulation part. And then there are those like Hickenlooper and Delaney who will capitalize on this, no pun intended, like Feinstein did in 1990 when she ran for California governor, which is proudly and defiantly saying, look, I'm not on the progressive left in this way. And therefore, I want to hold you, independents, for you to stay on board. Because look, I'm being booed by the socialists, help me to not elect Donald Trump again. Real quick to your point, though, about the progressive aspect. Of course, you are right historically that there are aspects of capitalism that kind of went unchecked. But overregulation is the reason that corner stores are stymied and that people cannot start businesses. It is not because of capitalism. It's the opposite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We'll give you the last word, Emily. All right. Conditions going from bad to worse in Los Angeles as fears of diseases now spreading across the city. Details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A growing problem in Los Angeles. Downtown getting overrun by the homeless population. Tent cities popping up everywhere. And decaying garbage also everywhere, rats running everywhere. There are so much trash in the streets that diseases like typhoid, apparently, are now spreading. The LAPD revealing that one of their own officers who patrol the area is now battling the disease. But despite all this bad news, Governor Newsom is still touting his state's success. He is tweeting, "California is what happens when rights are respected, when work is rewarded, when nature is protected, when diversity is celebrated and free markets are fair markets. We are nothing less than the progressive answer to a transgressive president." So, I go to Ms. California. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I think I'm too old for the competition now. What I say that is that I think what is paralyzing these cities in part is the war between the compassionate care approaches. So, Newsom represents just a small sliver of the competing theories of how to fix these problems. And the result is that we have a continued succession of short-term Band- Aids. Let's construct a bunch of outdoor toilets. Let's go in every day. You know, for example, in Portland let's spend $32 on teens that come in at every 6 a.m. and rose the homeless off the streets and clean them only to return the next day because it crops up. It's mowing the lawn to the detriment of not only the homeless, 80 percent of whom are drug addicted and over 60 percent of whom are mentally ill and also the constituents who, for example, in Seattle, voted against say, the safe needle depository situation. Public health officials overrode it in court and said, no, that's not for citizens to do. So, at this point, again, it's paralysis that is tripling these cities and its short-term solutions that are not doing anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now I go to Mr. California.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, thank you. I won that three years running. You can catch my pictures online. Dr. Drew has been predicting this for I don't know how many years. Every disease outbreak, he has predicted. The typhus. He mentioned and I'm pretty sure he said this. The next one is the plague.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That because of the insects, the flees are on rats are going to be there. And it's going to happen. And I think this is going to happen to a lot of -- you can see I'm now scratching.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: My God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK. I'm going to say something --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, you don't look so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't feel good. You are talking about 60 percent mentally ill. OK. There is the other 40 percent. There needs to be a brave politician who doesn't deal in word salad like what this, what he just did who makes to distinguish between the truly suffering, i.e., families and mentally ill and the young odious drifters that who capitalize on compassion for the suffering. The people who move there because the weather is great. They are vagrants, hustlers and bums who are portray themselves as down and out. I think that we have to make a distinction between the people who truly need help and the people who are just hanging there. Because New York would be like this except that we have a winter. that's why we don't have the problems. And the real disgrace for me, is that Hollywood makes billions off of creating dystopian fictions from "The Handmaid's Tale" to I don't know, what's the lady -- "The Hunger Games." The real dystopia is downtown. Go make that movie, Hollywood. The loudest voices on this won't leave their gated communities. So, the hypocrisy is we've lost the will, the moral will to disperse and relocate the people that are helpless, diseased and the suffering and get the others out now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Dana, you know, I don't think we -- it's not that we think that poor people and homeless people are diseased. We are just saying this is a tragedy going on in big cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not just trash.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a crime against humanity.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It is an outrage. I mean, obviously, we have the will and the means and the resources to be able to deal with this problem. If they wanted to deal with it, they actually could.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, Steve Lopez.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't -- why do you say that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because this is America and we have all the tools at our disposal to be able to deal with this issue if we choose to. They are choosing not to. Steve Lopez is an L.A. Times reporter, who wrote very movingly after all of his reporting. One of the things he talked about is some of these people that are living in a tent or have like a low area. Let's say they have to go to the hospital. They come back they find out that their stuff has been either burned or it's been taken or somebody else has moved in. And it's just -- the cycle of badness continues. In addition to that, one of the guys that he interviews says that he sees every night these people come and they dump huge bags of trash. And it's all of these like fruit peels and things like that from big restaurants. Because the city isn't keeping track of those restaurants or whoever it is that is doing really bad things. So, if you drop all that kind of food trash, what's it going to attract? Rats. So, they are not helping anybody. And the restaurants are getting away with it. I absolutely think that they have the means. You talk about somebody like Rudy Giuliani did here in the city, you can disagree around like certain things. But this city turns around, yes. Every one of us in America, we could fix this problem. And the City Council has - they have a lot more to do than to just give us - we feel really bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And nuisance. That was a word salad, did not address--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I didn't even understand that that was supposed to be addressed in LA--

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Well, his policy failed in San Francisco when he tried the Care Not Cash program. So, he has a long history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, Jesse, let me ask you to help us wrap this up because to me just living in America, I see more homeless people than I think I've seen in my lifetime on the streets. And I don't care what city I'm in, but I just think Dana says we know how to deal with this. I think people would welcome great ideas because a lot of the homeless people, if you even like try to give them money or try to be helpful they don't even want to accept your help or they say, I don't want to go to the shelter or whatever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Greg said, you need a brave politician which is an oxymoron. No one wants to handle it. And this is just like the border crisis, liberals created a crisis and now they have no solutions. But the difference is, they can't blame Republicans or Donald Trump for this, because Democrats have run this city, they control the city council and they control the mayor's office. They've allowed this thing to fester, because they allow anything to happen and now it's a radius, a 50 block radius and they thought they had it contained, but now it started to infect other people, people go into this place, but they don't come out. I went in there one time with a camera crew and we just drove around, and we wouldn't leave the car, because it was so dangerous. We saw drugged out zombies chasing barefooted babies through piles of garbage with hypodermic needles and fire everywhere. It was the most depraved and disgusting thing I've ever seen in my life and.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's saying a lot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that's saying a lot. And I've been around, and you only have one solution. You bulldoze the 50 block radius and you institutionalize everybody and detoxify them and then you let them out because right now to let it happen, police are going to get infected, then their families are going to get infected and that's going to be a long-term economic and health crisis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You realize--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nipped in the bud--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You realize it was Republicans who focused on deinstitutionalization.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Quick point about that one--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to play the blame game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You did, you blamed it on liberal. You said it was Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Healed and they need to spend the money to do it--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because they know they have plenty of it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: In Seattle, when a journalist suggested institutionalization or simply mental health facilities, a Seattle City Council member called the journalists a Nazi in a public hearing. So that's the level of the Left that we're dealing with where any type of reasonable approach is shot down and labeled in that way. WATTERS: Right. They want to have a third world country in their city, look at it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's fifth world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Look at it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: If we're dealing with typhoid and the plague that's dark ages, that's Middle Ages.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, let's hope that doesn't happen. Up next, Hillary Clinton goes Hollywood. New details on Clinton testing the waters in Tinseltown. When we come back for your fun on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: After failing in her political run for president, Hillary Clinton may now be setting her sights on Hollywood. Clinton is reportedly teaming up with her daughter Chelsea to form a production company to make film and TV projects that would emphasize stories by and about women. The move follows in the footsteps of the Obamas who also created their own production company and have a deal at Netflix. OK, so Greg--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why me?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: This is probably not about women, right. This is probably just still all about Hillary Clinton. GUTFELD: Well, I think it's like a consolation prize, if you can't be president have a Netflix documentary about how you weren't president. As I get it, it's kind of interesting to see Trump and her switch places. He went from entertainment to politics. Now she's going to politics to entertainment, which leads me to the suggestion, she should host the new Apprentice. Wouldn't that be amazing if she--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That would be - and what if the ratings were bigger than his ratings. It would drive him crazy. It just isn't that the perfect thing that could happen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one wants to watch Hillary. Americans had the choice; she ran for president twice and they were both like click next guy. I mean she's boring. She has boring tastes. I don't think anybody cares what she's into. This is a vanity project for herself and for Chelsea. She doesn't understand how hard producing compelling television and film is, it's one of the most competitive industries in the entertainment industry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tell us Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You go to Greg, you're the new king of late night. And so how arrogant of her to think that she can just swoop in and produce this stuff that people want to watch. She's really not going to lift much of a finger, she's going to put her name on a few things and then go to the premiere and walk the red carpet. But don't they have enough propagandists in the media. They have the newspapers; they have the networks. What more do they want? And Greg's point, I mean Donald Trump is probably the most successful television producer out there and he's producing a hell of a great presidency right now. No one is going to watch Netflix when you can watch Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. And there is never a repeat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. All fresh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. So, Hollywood has given the Clintons so much money. Think about how much money they have donated to the Clintons since 1990 when he was running for governor and then for president and for re-election and then her campaigns and then you had the Clinton Global Initiative and then she runs for president again. There is so much money and now they're like oh and actually we'll let you do this too. I think this isn't going to continue the Obama versus the Clinton feud, because the Obamas have that big deal with Netflix and so it'll just continue. I also have this really strong urge to go back to the previous block and to complain about something. GUTFELD: What.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. So, the question was, do we have the wherewithal and the resources to be able to do this? OK. I'm sorry but we are about to honor and observe the 75th anniversary of D-Day, going back to 1944. And we don't think we have the wherewithal and the ability to actually deal with a crisis in the city of Los Angeles with its 50 blocks. I mean I'm pretty sure Americans can figure out how to get that done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, can I go back to a block from Friday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know I haven't had that urge in so long.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what it is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whole Pandora's Box. WILLIAMS: I know why that is. You wanted to respond to me, and I appreciate it. Because I think it's a legitimate--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I did respond to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's a legitimate concern but I'm looking for ideas because I think there are people who wanted--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Can we just stick to bashing Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Anyway OK. Let me just say this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jerks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Recall this. When you guys look at why you know huge book deals come in for Obamas and the Clintons or now Obama has a deal with Netflix right. And I think Clinton is going to get a deal. Why? Because guess what? We believe in capitalism and these corporations say, hey, there is a huge demand for political content right now. Not only on the cable channels, but you look at Facebook, you look at the newspapers that are doing so well. People want political content and this guess what, Obama and Clinton are going to provide--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think the content is being forced down the viewers' throat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When there is an ex-President like Barack Obama comes to Netflix and say, hey, you know what, I'm thinking about doing some film. What do you think Netflix is going to say Juan, no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, because--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The hat.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There is obviously there is an anti-Trump crowd there in London but it's like saying that New York City is America. London is not the U.K.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And there is a large groundswell of support for President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This Brexit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, they wish that Theresa May had been a little bit more like him in pushing back against the E.U. and trying to get out of the Brexit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't Brexit really the response to the media the way Trump was a response to the media here?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. But the politicians in the U.K. couldn't pull it off.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that it was even more -- I think it's actually even worse than that which is that it was supposed to be like an economic arrangement and it turned into the E.U. who's trying to make all of their rules to try to -- that change. They wanted to change the U.K.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's talk about --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do get nervous watching American politicians try to play the Aneka (Ph) game.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, you watch them and they don't know what to do with their glass and where --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is why we had the war.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you know what? This is good. We shouldn't know. We're the rebels.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They don't want to play that game.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Is that American press to go --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let them disappearing --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But my problem -- but my problem I don't think that you said, hey, why is he bothering to even meet with the mayor? Why should he meet with the mayor? The guy is a mayor. He is a world leader. But he's got to meet with Theresa May who is having trouble with Brexit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, he is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And what does he say about Brexit? Theresa May, you should have done better. You should have done this. You should have more like me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, that's our representative.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But she is the -- my point is, why would you meet with the mayor? Meeting with Theresa May. She is like the leader of leader of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but he is the one who has been undermining her and I don't think that's polite. By the way, Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you put on that hat, I think you would look --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you'd look -- you'd look the same exact outfit.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There is the hat. Go, Emily, go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where is the hat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Come everybody.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I await my invitation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Hey, one last question. How does Peter feel about the John Cleese stuff? Does he? But John Cleese get -- we can talk about it during the break.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know Peter. Like you can imagine how he feels. He's like you'll always get in trouble for speaking the truth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. All right. I'll leave it at that. Leave it at that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't even know what that means. OK. Two 2020 Democrats getting booed by their party for bashing socialism and Medicare for all. The video next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Democratic Party divisions in the spotlight as 2020 hopefuls spoke at this weekend's California Democratic Party convention. Two contenders being booed when they went against the party's growing progressive agenda. First up, former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper takes a stance against socialism.

utterances.speaker: FMR. GOV. JOHN HICKENLOOPER (D-CO)
utterances.utterance: If we want to beat Donald Trump and achieve big progressive goals, socialism is not the answer.

utterances.speaker: HICKENLOOPER
utterances.utterance: I was re-elected -- I was re-elected in a purple state in 2014, one of the worst years for Democrats in a quarter century. You know, if we're not careful, we're going to end up helping to re-elect the worst president in American history.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And former Maryland Congressman John Delaney also got an earful from the crowd when he criticized Medicare for all.

utterances.speaker: FMR. REP. JOHN DELANEY (D-MD)
utterances.utterance: What we need as Democrats to build an economy that works but it's got to be with smart policies. Medicare for all may sound good. But it's actually, not good policy nor is it good politics. I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: DELANEY
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you. A hundred.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So, this was, Greg, a California state convention.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so, it's basically who goes to the California state convention on a summer weekend, the very faithful, the most activists and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We saw them with the personification of Twitter.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They went on to -- he went on to Twitter and said, hey, if you guys want to win, don't be crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He got ratioed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he got ratioed. He got ratioed. He was like, they were basically booing the adult in the room. And the adult understands that to get, you know, to have goals you need means. You need to create in order then to make or spread around. And socialism just takes over the means of production and that doesn't work. So, I mean, it is -- I mean, I thought Hickenlooper was brave. That's not good for them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because he was like, I was thinking of your book, "The Bible of Unspeakable Truths." He told a truth. And at least now, though, we are talking about Hickenlooper.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really? Are we, though? I think we are talking about socialism. I am going to say this again, because it's worth repeating.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Democratic candidate can't win the primary without socialism but they can't win the general with it. And that's the catch 22 that they face. I'm beginning to think socialism is just a wrecking ball to destroy capitalism. Because no one really believes and understands how socialism is going to work because it has never anywhere. It has never worked in Venezuela. They tried Medicare for all in Vermont. Obamacare failed nationally. Socialism doesn't actually work. It's just used to destroy capitalism. So actually, the people pushing socialism are just anarchists. Over to you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I must say, I'm so interested in this. First of all, I think it's a fever dream on the part of Republicans to think that somehow Democrats are going so far left. Hickenlooper, let's talk about Hickenlooper even though I don't think he is going anywhere. But let's talk about Hickenlooper. You say Hickenlooper gets booed. Hickenlooper is a strong progressive, Jesse. Hickenlooper, for example, he talks about capitalism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But still got booed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He still got booed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. On the socialism because I think he put it out there in a way. And I would pick up on the point made earlier. That this is a California Democratic convention. So, you are getting a representation that is the far left. Then that's like saying you have a convention of the Freedom Caucus and it represents all Republicans. I don't think so. Anyway, to my mind, Hickenlooper is talking about capitalism being broken. He says there are only two companies in America that sell 80 percent of all the hardware goods in the country. He says that's not right. What happened to forcing back against the monopoly so the little guy has a chance to open a corner store, or a neighborhood store and do well. That's not what's happening. We have fewer and fewer companies being started in America. That's not evidence of what it takes to have a solid middle-class growth in America. So, if you are talking about Hickenlooper, remember, he is a strong progressive. It's Republicans who want to label everything socialism. And what he was saying was, don't fall into the Republican trap because then they'll all say we're all socialists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they still booed him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. But, Juan, the great American success story is because of capitalism, it's not because of socialism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. It's because we've --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can now say the best economy we've had in 30 years --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, what I'm saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- because capitalism is broken.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Before Emily comes, let me just quickly respond.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because capitalism has been unleashed successfully.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. You can't. You have to understand. We -- I mean, everything from child labor to monopolies, to what happens in 2008 and 2009 with unregulated Wall Street almost crashing our economy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, talk about monopoly --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We had to restrain capitalism.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- the Trump administration actually just took anti-monopolistic action against some of the big Silicon Valley company.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can we get Emily in?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What I was saying, we have when you think about income inequality, we have equality.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Income inequality is big in California --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. It's big --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- the Democrats have a super majority.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Go, Emily.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily, Bernie Sanders was in The New York Times today. I won't read the whole thing but he has an op-ed, basically saying that lays out his economic argument. And he also took aim at capitalism and the wealthy saying that we've got it all wrong here in America.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I think that goes into what you are saying where right now that's the best argument. I think it's a -- we are seeing two responses to this, which is either appeasing the Democratic minority of the socialists. Bernie, obviously he's the O.G. He firmly believes it. People like Governor Inslee, however, who came on after Hickenlooper personifies to me kind of personifies that capitulation part. And then there are those like Hickenlooper and Delaney who will capitalize on this, no pun intended, like Feinstein did in 1990 when she ran for California governor, which is proudly and defiantly saying, look, I'm not on the progressive left in this way. And therefore, I want to hold you, independents, for you to stay on board. Because look, I'm being booed by the socialists, help me to not elect Donald Trump again. Real quick to your point, though, about the progressive aspect. Of course, you are right historically that there are aspects of capitalism that kind of went unchecked. But overregulation is the reason that corner stores are stymied and that people cannot start businesses. It is not because of capitalism. It's the opposite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll give you the last word, Emily. All right. Conditions going from bad to worse in Los Angeles as fears of diseases now spreading across the city. Details ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A growing problem in Los Angeles. Downtown getting overrun by the homeless population. Tent cities popping up everywhere. And decaying garbage also everywhere, rats running everywhere. There are so much trash in the streets that diseases like typhoid, apparently, are now spreading. The LAPD revealing that one of their own officers who patrol the area is now battling the disease. But despite all this bad news, Governor Newsom is still touting his state's success. He is tweeting, "California is what happens when rights are respected, when work is rewarded, when nature is protected, when diversity is celebrated and free markets are fair markets. We are nothing less than the progressive answer to a transgressive president." So, I go to Ms. California. What do you say?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I think I'm too old for the competition now. What I say that is that I think what is paralyzing these cities in part is the war between the compassionate care approaches. So, Newsom represents just a small sliver of the competing theories of how to fix these problems. And the result is that we have a continued succession of short-term Band- Aids. Let's construct a bunch of outdoor toilets. Let's go in every day. You know, for example, in Portland let's spend $32 on teens that come in at every 6 a.m. and rose the homeless off the streets and clean them only to return the next day because it crops up. It's mowing the lawn to the detriment of not only the homeless, 80 percent of whom are drug addicted and over 60 percent of whom are mentally ill and also the constituents who, for example, in Seattle, voted against say, the safe needle depository situation. Public health officials overrode it in court and said, no, that's not for citizens to do. So, at this point, again, it's paralysis that is tripling these cities and its short-term solutions that are not doing anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Now I go to Mr. California.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, thank you. I won that three years running. You can catch my pictures online. Dr. Drew has been predicting this for I don't know how many years. Every disease outbreak, he has predicted. The typhus. He mentioned and I'm pretty sure he said this. The next one is the plague.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That because of the insects, the flees are on rats are going to be there. And it's going to happen. And I think this is going to happen to a lot of -- you can see I'm now scratching.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: My God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. I'm going to say something --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, you don't look so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't feel good. You are talking about 60 percent mentally ill. OK. There is the other 40 percent. There needs to be a brave politician who doesn't deal in word salad like what this, what he just did who makes to distinguish between the truly suffering, i.e., families and mentally ill and the young odious drifters that who capitalize on compassion for the suffering. The people who move there because the weather is great. They are vagrants, hustlers and bums who are portray themselves as down and out. I think that we have to make a distinction between the people who truly need help and the people who are just hanging there. Because New York would be like this except that we have a winter. that's why we don't have the problems. And the real disgrace for me, is that Hollywood makes billions off of creating dystopian fictions from "The Handmaid's Tale" to I don't know, what's the lady -- "The Hunger Games." The real dystopia is downtown. Go make that movie, Hollywood. The loudest voices on this won't leave their gated communities. So, the hypocrisy is we've lost the will, the moral will to disperse and relocate the people that are helpless, diseased and the suffering and get the others out now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Dana, you know, I don't think we -- it's not that we think that poor people and homeless people are diseased. We are just saying this is a tragedy going on in big cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not just trash.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a crime against humanity.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is an outrage. I mean, obviously, we have the will and the means and the resources to be able to deal with this problem. If they wanted to deal with it, they actually could.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, Steve Lopez.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't -- why do you say that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because this is America and we have all the tools at our disposal to be able to deal with this issue if we choose to. They are choosing not to. Steve Lopez is an L.A. Times reporter, who wrote very movingly after all of his reporting. One of the things he talked about is some of these people that are living in a tent or have like a low area. Let's say they have to go to the hospital. They come back they find out that their stuff has been either burned or it's been taken or somebody else has moved in. And it's just -- the cycle of badness continues. In addition to that, one of the guys that he interviews says that he sees every night these people come and they dump huge bags of trash. And it's all of these like fruit peels and things like that from big restaurants. Because the city isn't keeping track of those restaurants or whoever it is that is doing really bad things. So, if you drop all that kind of food trash, what's it going to attract? Rats. So, they are not helping anybody. And the restaurants are getting away with it. I absolutely think that they have the means. You talk about somebody like Rudy Giuliani did here in the city, you can disagree around like certain things. But this city turns around, yes. Every one of us in America, we could fix this problem. And the City Council has - they have a lot more to do than to just give us - we feel really bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And nuisance. That was a word salad, did not address--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I didn't even understand that that was supposed to be addressed in LA--

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, his policy failed in San Francisco when he tried the Care Not Cash program. So, he has a long history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, Jesse, let me ask you to help us wrap this up because to me just living in America, I see more homeless people than I think I've seen in my lifetime on the streets. And I don't care what city I'm in, but I just think Dana says we know how to deal with this. I think people would welcome great ideas because a lot of the homeless people, if you even like try to give them money or try to be helpful they don't even want to accept your help or they say, I don't want to go to the shelter or whatever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, Greg said, you need a brave politician which is an oxymoron. No one wants to handle it. And this is just like the border crisis, liberals created a crisis and now they have no solutions. But the difference is, they can't blame Republicans or Donald Trump for this, because Democrats have run this city, they control the city council and they control the mayor's office. They've allowed this thing to fester, because they allow anything to happen and now it's a radius, a 50 block radius and they thought they had it contained, but now it started to infect other people, people go into this place, but they don't come out. I went in there one time with a camera crew and we just drove around, and we wouldn't leave the car, because it was so dangerous. We saw drugged out zombies chasing barefooted babies through piles of garbage with hypodermic needles and fire everywhere. It was the most depraved and disgusting thing I've ever seen in my life and.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's saying a lot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's saying a lot. And I've been around, and you only have one solution. You bulldoze the 50 block radius and you institutionalize everybody and detoxify them and then you let them out because right now to let it happen, police are going to get infected, then their families are going to get infected and that's going to be a long-term economic and health crisis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You realize--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nipped in the bud--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You realize it was Republicans who focused on deinstitutionalization.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Quick point about that one--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to play the blame game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You did, you blamed it on liberal. You said it was Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Healed and they need to spend the money to do it--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because they know they have plenty of it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: In Seattle, when a journalist suggested institutionalization or simply mental health facilities, a Seattle City Council member called the journalists a Nazi in a public hearing. So that's the level of the Left that we're dealing with where any type of reasonable approach is shot down and labeled in that way. WATTERS: Right. They want to have a third world country in their city, look at it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's fifth world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Look at it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: If we're dealing with typhoid and the plague that's dark ages, that's Middle Ages.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, let's hope that doesn't happen. Up next, Hillary Clinton goes Hollywood. New details on Clinton testing the waters in Tinseltown. When we come back for your fun on THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: After failing in her political run for president, Hillary Clinton may now be setting her sights on Hollywood. Clinton is reportedly teaming up with her daughter Chelsea to form a production company to make film and TV projects that would emphasize stories by and about women. The move follows in the footsteps of the Obamas who also created their own production company and have a deal at Netflix. OK, so Greg--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why me?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: This is probably not about women, right. This is probably just still all about Hillary Clinton. GUTFELD: Well, I think it's like a consolation prize, if you can't be president have a Netflix documentary about how you weren't president. As I get it, it's kind of interesting to see Trump and her switch places. He went from entertainment to politics. Now she's going to politics to entertainment, which leads me to the suggestion, she should host the new Apprentice. Wouldn't that be amazing if she--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That would be - and what if the ratings were bigger than his ratings. It would drive him crazy. It just isn't that the perfect thing that could happen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one wants to watch Hillary. Americans had the choice; she ran for president twice and they were both like click next guy. I mean she's boring. She has boring tastes. I don't think anybody cares what she's into. This is a vanity project for herself and for Chelsea. She doesn't understand how hard producing compelling television and film is, it's one of the most competitive industries in the entertainment industry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tell us Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You go to Greg, you're the new king of late night. And so how arrogant of her to think that she can just swoop in and produce this stuff that people want to watch. She's really not going to lift much of a finger, she's going to put her name on a few things and then go to the premiere and walk the red carpet. But don't they have enough propagandists in the media. They have the newspapers; they have the networks. What more do they want? And Greg's point, I mean Donald Trump is probably the most successful television producer out there and he's producing a hell of a great presidency right now. No one is going to watch Netflix when you can watch Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And there is never a repeat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. All fresh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Hollywood has given the Clintons so much money. Think about how much money they have donated to the Clintons since 1990 when he was running for governor and then for president and for re-election and then her campaigns and then you had the Clinton Global Initiative and then she runs for president again. There is so much money and now they're like oh and actually we'll let you do this too. I think this isn't going to continue the Obama versus the Clinton feud, because the Obamas have that big deal with Netflix and so it'll just continue. I also have this really strong urge to go back to the previous block and to complain about something. GUTFELD: What.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So, the question was, do we have the wherewithal and the resources to be able to do this? OK. I'm sorry but we are about to honor and observe the 75th anniversary of D-Day, going back to 1944. And we don't think we have the wherewithal and the ability to actually deal with a crisis in the city of Los Angeles with its 50 blocks. I mean I'm pretty sure Americans can figure out how to get that done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, can I go back to a block from Friday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know I haven't had that urge in so long.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what it is?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whole Pandora's Box. WILLIAMS: I know why that is. You wanted to respond to me, and I appreciate it. Because I think it's a legitimate--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I did respond to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's a legitimate concern but I'm looking for ideas because I think there are people who wanted--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can we just stick to bashing Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway OK. Let me just say this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jerks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Recall this. When you guys look at why you know huge book deals come in for Obamas and the Clintons or now Obama has a deal with Netflix right. And I think Clinton is going to get a deal. Why? Because guess what? We believe in capitalism and these corporations say, hey, there is a huge demand for political content right now. Not only on the cable channels, but you look at Facebook, you look at the newspapers that are doing so well. People want political content and this guess what, Obama and Clinton are going to provide--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think the content is being forced down the viewers' throat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
